column4: dudeee34: don't ask if anyone uses something, ask the question you have about it
I'm looking to get wake-on-wan working, wake-on-lan is set up and functional, but if I send the magic packet from outside my LAN, it's getting dropped/improperly forwarded by my router. Any suggests?
what kind of router is this?
i don't know if this will be possible with your router, unless you can run some type of script on it that can be called to wake up the machine in the LAN
is that because most routers drop multicast udp packets?
I have a web-based adminstration tool available on port 8080 coming from the router, but I don't see any way that I could run a script using it
iirc, WOL sends a magic layer-2 frame to a broadcast address (ff:ff:ff:ff:ff) -- and it's kinda impossible to send layer-2 traffic to a remote destination over the internet
the idea I had was for the packet to be sent to broadcast and therefor be sent to all connected devices
right, thats how WOL works anyway, but you can't send broadcast traffic over the internet
ah, I didn't know that. so what are you suggesting I try?
or what do people usually try if they want to wake up a machine over WAN? just log into a local machine to the one they want to wake up and send the magic packet from there?
my router is actually a linux machine, and i've set it upto run a script whenever i access a particular URL on it's webserver, the script then wakes up computer(s)

yeah, I've thought of doing that, though it'd be nice if I could just have the router up as I don't have an extra machine and the point of wake-on-wan (in my case) would be to wake up the desktop when I need to access it
yea, it kind is a limitation of SOHO routers ..
and thanks for clearing up the muddy water for me
